SECTION I.

Introduction

In this article, we focus on the MCP-regularized optimization problem \begin{equation*} \min \varphi (x):=f(x)+ \sum _{i=1}^{n} r_{i}(x_{i}),\tag{1}\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} \min \varphi (x):=f(x)+ \sum _{i=1}^{n} r_{i}(x_{i}),\tag{1}\end{equation*} where $f$ is continuously differentiable and \begin{align*} r_{i}(x_{i})=\begin{cases} \displaystyle \lambda \left({|x_{i}|-\frac {x_{i}^{2}}{2\lambda \theta }}\right),&{{ if}} |x_{i}| < \theta \lambda,\\ \displaystyle \frac {\lambda ^{2} \theta }{2},&{{ if}} |x_{i}|\geq \theta \lambda, \end{cases}\end{align*} View Source\begin{align*} r_{i}(x_{i})=\begin{cases} \displaystyle \lambda \left({|x_{i}|-\frac {x_{i}^{2}}{2\lambda \theta }}\right),&{{ if}} |x_{i}| < \theta \lambda,\\ \displaystyle \frac {\lambda ^{2} \theta }{2},&{{ if}} |x_{i}|\geq \theta \lambda, \end{cases}\end{align*} where $\lambda > 0$ and $\theta > 1$ . The MCP penalty is a fast, continuous, nearly unbiased and sparse penalty function [43]. An important application of (1), found in the signal processing literature, is the problem \begin{equation*} \min \frac {1}{2}\|Ax-b\|^{2}+ \sum _{i=1}^{n} r_{i}(x_{i})\tag{2}\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} \min \frac {1}{2}\|Ax-b\|^{2}+ \sum _{i=1}^{n} r_{i}(x_{i})\tag{2}\end{equation*} which approximates the known $\ell _{2}$ -$\ell _{0}$ \begin{equation*} \min \frac {1}{2}\|Ax-b\|^{2}+\|x\|_{0},\tag{3}\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} \min \frac {1}{2}\|Ax-b\|^{2}+\|x\|_{0},\tag{3}\end{equation*} where $A\in \mathcal {R}^{m\times n}$ and $b\in \mathcal {R}^{m}$ and the $\ell _{0}$ norm counts the nonzero entries of $x$ . The problems (1)–​(3) are used in many applications, such as in compressive sensing, high-dimensional variable selection, data fitting and image reconstruction ([5], [28], [40]).

A. Previous Works

Problem (3) is known to be NP-hard ([12], [30]) since it involves the $\ell _{0}$ norm and hence is a nonconvex and discontinuous optimization problem. Several different classes of approaches have been proposed to solve problem (3). Convex relaxation is the first class of methods in which the $\ell _{0}$ -norm is replaced by the convex $\ell _{1}$ -norm. One of the most popular methods in convex relaxation is the class of iterative shrinkage-thresholding algorithms (ISTA) and various variants ([2], [13], [25], [26], [40], [41]), where each iteration requires a matrix-vector multiplication involving $A$ and $A^{T}$ followed by a shrinkage/soft-threshold step. Other algorithms for the $l_{1}$ minimization include alternating direction method of multipliers SALSA [1]; coordinate-wise descent method [39]; projected gradient method [17]; reduced-space algorithm [10]; active set methods ([11], [26], [33]). We refer to papers ([10], [26]) for recent advances in this area.

Another class of methods to deal with $\ell _{0}$ optimization problem are greedy methods such as matching pursuit [29], orthogonal mathching pursuit (OMP) [32], CoSaMp [31] and single best replacement [35]. These greedy methods update the support of $x$ by exploiting the residual and then solve a least-squares problem on the support at each iteration. These type of algorithms are widely used in practice due to their relatively fast computational speed. Under a sufficient incoherence assumption, Tropp [38] proved that OMP recovers the sparsest representation of the input signal. We refer to a survey of greedy algorithms [37] for recent advances in this area.

The convexity of the $\ell _{1}$ penalty allows designing fast and global convergent algorithms. However, it has a drawback which requires more restrictive conditions on the matrix $A$ to establish the equivalent and unique global solution to model (3). In addition, it tends to produce biased estimated for larger coefficients and lacks oracle property [13], [14]. To overcome the drawback produced by the $\ell _{1}$ penalty, many continuous nonconvex approximations have been proposed to approach the $\ell _{0}$ -norm. Among the variety of $\ell _{0}$ -like continuous penalties, one can find the nonnegative garrote [6], log-sum penalty [7] and capped-$\ell _{1}$ [42]. Fan and Li [15] defined necessary conditions to obtain a ‘good’ penalty function (unbiasedness, continuity in data and sparsity) and proposed the smoothly clipped absolute deviation (SCAD) penalty. Fan and Li [16] discussed a variable splitting and penalty decomposition minimization technique for (2), along with other approximations of the $\ell _{0}$ -norm. Lv and Fan [27] used concave function on $\mathcal R_{+}$ to approximate the $\ell _{0}$ norm and proved a nonasymptotic nearly oracle property of the resultant estimator. Zhang [43] introduced the notion of sparse convexity to compare penalties and proposed the minimax concave penalty (MCP). Fourcat and Lai [19] investigated the use of $\ell _{p}$ -norm and an interesting work on the equivalence between minimal $\ell _{0}$ and $\ell _{p}$ ($0 < p < 1$ ) solutions of linear systems of equations (equality and inequality) was given in [20]. A general iterative shrinkage thresholding algorithm in [21] was proposed and illustrated on the SCAD, MCP and capped $\ell _{1}$ penalties. They also proved that the algorithm converged to a critical point. Fornasier and Ward [18] proposed an iterative thresholding algorithm for minimizing (2) where the $\ell _{0}$ norm is replaced by a reasonable sparsity-promoting relaxation and convergence to a local minimizer is established. In [44], zhang et al. proved that the transformed $\ell _{1}$ penalty can recover the exact solution of constrained $\ell _{0}$ norm with the null space property (NSP) and the restricted isometry property (RIP). They also presented two difference of convex algorithms for the transformed $\ell _{1}$ optimization which guarantee the convergence to a stationary point. Recently, Jiao et al. [24] developed a unified primal dual active set algorithm for a class of nonconvex sparsity penalties which includes $\ell _{0}$ , $\ell _{p}$ , SCAD, capped $\ell _{1}$ and MCP. Under the restricted isometry property, they proved the proposed algorithms converges to the underlying regression target. We refer to papers ([3], [4], [9], [24], [28], [34], [36], [45]) for recent advances in this area.

B. Our Work

In this article, we propose a second-order algorithm to solve problem (1). The main contributions of our paper can be summarized as follows.

  1. We provide two optimal property of problem (1). One shows that the support set of a local minimizer corresponds to linearly independent columns of $A$ , the other provides two sufficient conditions for a stationary point to be a local minimizer point.

  2. We introduce an active set identification technique. An attractive advantage of the identification technique is that it can accurately identify the zero components in a neighbourhood of a stationary point of problem (1).

  3. By means of the identification technique, we propose a second-order algorithm for solving (1.1). To accelerate the convergence of the algorithm, the nonmonotone line search [22] is used. We prove that every accumulation point of the sequence generated by the new algorithm is a stationary point of problem (1).

  4. We do comprehensive numerical experiments to show the efficiency of the proposed algorithm. Numerical results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm is competitive with several known methods.

The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. Two optimal properties related to (1) are given in Section II. The active set estimate is presented in Section III. In Section IV, we propose the algorithm and establish the global convergence of the algorithm. We report some numerical results in Section V and make some conclusions in section VI.

SECTION II.

Optimal Properties

In this section, we provide two optimal property of problem (1). We begin with some notations. A point $\bar {x} \in \mathcal R^{n}$ is a stationary point of problem (1) if it satisfies the following system \begin{align*} \begin{cases} \displaystyle |g_{i}(\bar {x})| \leq \lambda,&{{ if}}\, \bar {x}_{i}=0,\\ \displaystyle g_{i}(\bar {x})=0, & {{ if}}\, |\bar {x}_{i}| > \theta \lambda, \\ \displaystyle g_{i}(\bar {x})+{{ sgn}}(\bar {x}_{i})\lambda -\frac {1}{\theta }\bar {x}_{i}=0,\;\; & {{ if}}\;\; 0 < |\bar {x}_{i}| < \theta \lambda,\\ \displaystyle g_{i}(\bar {x})=0 & {{ if}}\, |\bar {x}_{i}|=\theta \lambda, \end{cases}\tag{4}\end{align*} View Source\begin{align*} \begin{cases} \displaystyle |g_{i}(\bar {x})| \leq \lambda,&{{ if}}\, \bar {x}_{i}=0,\\ \displaystyle g_{i}(\bar {x})=0, & {{ if}}\, |\bar {x}_{i}| > \theta \lambda, \\ \displaystyle g_{i}(\bar {x})+{{ sgn}}(\bar {x}_{i})\lambda -\frac {1}{\theta }\bar {x}_{i}=0,\;\; & {{ if}}\;\; 0 < |\bar {x}_{i}| < \theta \lambda,\\ \displaystyle g_{i}(\bar {x})=0 & {{ if}}\, |\bar {x}_{i}|=\theta \lambda, \end{cases}\tag{4}\end{align*} where $g_{i}(x)$ is the $i$ th component of the gradient vector of $f(x)$ and ${{ sgn}}(t): \mathcal R\rightarrow \mathcal R$ is the $sign$ function defined by \begin{align*} {{ sgn}}(t)= \begin{cases} \displaystyle 1, &{\text if } t > 0; \\ \displaystyle 0, &{\text if } t=0;\\ \displaystyle -1,& {\text if} t < 0. \end{cases}\end{align*} View Source\begin{align*} {{ sgn}}(t)= \begin{cases} \displaystyle 1, &{\text if } t > 0; \\ \displaystyle 0, &{\text if } t=0;\\ \displaystyle -1,& {\text if} t < 0. \end{cases}\end{align*} We use the set ${\mathcal T}(\bar {x})$ to denote the support of $\bar {x}$ and use the set ${\mathcal G(\bar {x})}$ to be the set of indices corresponding to the zero components of $\bar {x}$ . Namely, \begin{equation*} {\mathcal G}(\bar {x})=\{i: \bar {x}_{i}=0\} \quad \text {and } {\mathcal T}(\bar {x})=\{i: \bar {x}_{i}\neq 0\}.\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} {\mathcal G}(\bar {x})=\{i: \bar {x}_{i}=0\} \quad \text {and } {\mathcal T}(\bar {x})=\{i: \bar {x}_{i}\neq 0\}.\end{equation*} The set ${\mathcal G(\bar {x})}$ can be subdivided into the following two sets \begin{equation*} {\mathcal G}_{+}(\bar {x})=\{i\in {\mathcal G} (\bar {x}): \, |g_{i}(\bar {x})| < \lambda \}\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} {\mathcal G}_{+}(\bar {x})=\{i\in {\mathcal G} (\bar {x}): \, |g_{i}(\bar {x})| < \lambda \}\end{equation*} and \begin{equation*} {\mathcal G}_{-}(\bar {x})=\{i \in {\mathcal G} (\bar {x}): \, |g_{i}(\bar {x})|=\lambda \}.\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} {\mathcal G}_{-}(\bar {x})=\{i \in {\mathcal G} (\bar {x}): \, |g_{i}(\bar {x})|=\lambda \}.\end{equation*} The support ${\mathcal T}(\bar {x})$ can be subdivided into the following three sets \begin{equation*} {\mathcal T}_{1}(\bar {x})=\{i:0 < |\bar {x}_{i}| < \lambda \theta \},\quad {\mathcal T}_{2}(\bar {x})=\{i: |\bar {x}_{i}| > \lambda \theta \}\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} {\mathcal T}_{1}(\bar {x})=\{i:0 < |\bar {x}_{i}| < \lambda \theta \},\quad {\mathcal T}_{2}(\bar {x})=\{i: |\bar {x}_{i}| > \lambda \theta \}\end{equation*} and \begin{equation*} {\mathcal T}_{3}(\bar {x})=\{i:|\bar {x}_{i}|=\lambda \theta \}.\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} {\mathcal T}_{3}(\bar {x})=\{i:|\bar {x}_{i}|=\lambda \theta \}.\end{equation*}

The following property shows that if $\bar {x}$ is a local minimizer of problem (2), then the columns of $A_{\mathcal T(\bar {x})}$ are linearly independent. Namely, the sparsity of the local minimizer is at most $rank(A)$ .

Theorem 1:

Suppose that $\bar {x}$ is a local minimizer of problem (2), then $A_{\mathcal T{(\bar {x})}}$ is of full column rank, i.e., columns of $A_{\mathcal T{(\bar {x})}}$ are linearly independent.

Proof:

Since $\bar {x}$ is a local minimizer of problem (2), there exists a neighbourhood $N(\bar {x},r)$ of $\bar {x}$ such that \begin{equation*} \varphi (x)\geq \varphi (\bar {x}),\quad \forall x\in N(\bar {x},r).\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} \varphi (x)\geq \varphi (\bar {x}),\quad \forall x\in N(\bar {x},r).\end{equation*} Assume that columns of $A_{\mathcal T{(\bar {x})}}$ are not linearly independent. Then there exists a vector $0\neq p=(p_{\mathcal T{(\bar {x})}},0)$ such that \begin{equation*} A_{\mathcal T{(\bar {x})}}p_{\mathcal T{(\bar {x})}}=0.\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} A_{\mathcal T{(\bar {x})}}p_{\mathcal T{(\bar {x})}}=0.\end{equation*} Consequently, we have \begin{equation*} Ap=0\;\; {{ and }}\,\;\; {\mathcal T}(p)\subseteq {\mathcal T} (\bar {x}).\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} Ap=0\;\; {{ and }}\,\;\; {\mathcal T}(p)\subseteq {\mathcal T} (\bar {x}).\end{equation*} Further, we can scale $p$ such that \begin{equation*} \|p\| < \min \{r,|\bar {x}_{i}|, i\in {\mathcal T} (\bar {x}) \}.\tag{5}\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} \|p\| < \min \{r,|\bar {x}_{i}|, i\in {\mathcal T} (\bar {x}) \}.\tag{5}\end{equation*} Let $\xi ^{1}=\bar {x}+p$ and $\xi ^{2}=\bar {x}-p$ . By (5) and the definition of $p$ , we have \begin{equation*} {{ sgn}}(\bar {x}_{i})={{ sgn}}(\xi ^{1}_{i})={{ sgn}}(\xi ^{2}_{i}),\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} {{ sgn}}(\bar {x}_{i})={{ sgn}}(\xi ^{1}_{i})={{ sgn}}(\xi ^{2}_{i}),\end{equation*} for any index $i$ which means that \begin{equation*} \frac {1}{2}|\xi ^{1}|+\frac {1}{2}|\xi ^{2}|=\frac {1}{2}|\xi ^{1}+\xi ^{2}|.\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} \frac {1}{2}|\xi ^{1}|+\frac {1}{2}|\xi ^{2}|=\frac {1}{2}|\xi ^{1}+\xi ^{2}|.\end{equation*} Since $r_{i}(t)$ is strictly concave for $t > 0$ , we have \begin{equation*} \frac {1}{2} r_{i}(|\xi ^{1}_{i}|)+\frac {1}{2} r_{i}(|\xi ^{2}_{i}|) < r_{i}\left({\frac {|\xi ^{1}_{i}+\xi ^{2}_{i}|}{2}}\right)=r_{i}(\bar {x}_{i}).\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} \frac {1}{2} r_{i}(|\xi ^{1}_{i}|)+\frac {1}{2} r_{i}(|\xi ^{2}_{i}|) < r_{i}\left({\frac {|\xi ^{1}_{i}+\xi ^{2}_{i}|}{2}}\right)=r_{i}(\bar {x}_{i}).\end{equation*} Thus, we (\varphi (\xi ^{1}),\varphi (\xi ^{2}))\leq&\frac {1}{2}\varphi (\xi ^{1})+ \frac {1}{2}\varphi (\xi ^{2})\\[3pt]=&\frac {1}{4}\|A\xi ^{1}-b\|^{2}+ \frac {1}{4}\|A\xi ^{2}-b\|^{2}\\[3pt]&+\, \sum The proof is completed.

Chen et al. [8] gave an affine-scaled second-order sufficient condition for local minimizers of nonconvex penalties which include the MCP penalty. However, it is difficult to verify the condition. Jiao et al. [24] gave a second-order sufficient condition for a stationary point to be a local minimizer point of (2). Below we provide two sufficient conditions for a stationary point to be a local minimizer point of (1). Condition (6) is an extension of the result [24].

Theorem 2:

Suppose that $f$ is twice continuously differentiable and $\bar {x}$ is a stationary point of problem (1). If \begin{equation*} \bar {\lambda }_{\min } > \frac {1}{\theta }\quad {{ and}}\, \|g_{\mathcal G(\bar {x})}(\bar {x})\|_{\infty } < \lambda\tag{6}\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} \bar {\lambda }_{\min } > \frac {1}{\theta }\quad {{ and}}\, \|g_{\mathcal G(\bar {x})}(\bar {x})\|_{\infty } < \lambda\tag{6}\end{equation*} or $\lambda _{\min } > \frac {1}{\theta } $ where $\bar {\lambda }_{\min }$ denotes the minimizer eigenvalue of the matrix $\nabla ^{2} f(\bar {x})_{\mathcal T(\bar {x}), {\mathcal T}(\bar {x})}$ and $\lambda _{\min }$ denotes the minimizer eigenvalue of the matrix $\nabla ^{2} f(\bar {x})$ , then $\bar {x}$ is a local minimizer point of problem (1).

Proof:

Suppose condition (6) holds. If ${\mathcal T}(\bar {x})=\emptyset $ , the conclusion is clearly. Suppose that ${\mathcal T}(\bar {x})\neq \emptyset $ . We shall prove that $\varphi (\bar {x}+ d)\geq \varphi (\bar {x}) $ for any sufficiently small $0\neq d\in \mathcal R^{n}$ . We shall consider two different cases. Note that \begin{equation*} |\bar {x}_{i}+d_{i}|-|\bar {x}_{i}|= {{ sgn}}(\bar {x}_{i})d_{i},\quad {{ as}}\, \|d\|\rightarrow 0 {{ and }} \,\bar {x}_{i}\neq 0.\tag{7}\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} |\bar {x}_{i}+d_{i}|-|\bar {x}_{i}|= {{ sgn}}(\bar {x}_{i})d_{i},\quad {{ as}}\, \|d\|\rightarrow 0 {{ and }} \,\bar {x}_{i}\neq 0.\tag{7}\end{equation*} Case (1) $d_{\mathcal G(\bar {x})}\neq 0$ . For any sufficiently small vector $0\neq d\in \mathcal R^{n}$ , we have \begin{align*}&\hspace {-2pc}\varphi (\bar {x}+d)-\varphi (\bar {x}) \\[1pt]=&f(\bar {x}+d)-f(\bar {x})+\sum _{i=1}^{n} (r_{i}(\bar {x}_{i}+d_{i})-r_{i}(\bar {x}_{i})) \\[1pt]=&g(\bar {x})^{T}d+\sum _{|\bar {x}_{i}|\leq \theta \lambda }(r_{i}(\bar {x}_{i}+d_{i})-r_{i}(\bar {x}_{i})) +o(\|d\|) \\[1pt]=&\sum _{\bar {x}_{i}=0}(g_{i}(\bar {x})^{T}d_{i}+\lambda |d_{i}|)\\[1pt]&+\, \sum _{0 < |\bar {x}_{i}|\leq \theta \lambda }(g_{i}(\bar {x})+\nabla r_{i}(\bar {x}))d_{i}+ o(\|d\|)\\[1pt]\geq&\sum _{\bar {x}_{i}=0}(\lambda -|g_{i}(\bar {x}))|d_{i}\\[1pt] > &0.\end{align*} View Source\begin{align*}&\hspace {-2pc}\varphi (\bar {x}+d)-\varphi (\bar {x}) \\[1pt]=&f(\bar {x}+d)-f(\bar {x})+\sum _{i=1}^{n} (r_{i}(\bar {x}_{i}+d_{i})-r_{i}(\bar {x}_{i})) \\[1pt]=&g(\bar {x})^{T}d+\sum _{|\bar {x}_{i}|\leq \theta \lambda }(r_{i}(\bar {x}_{i}+d_{i})-r_{i}(\bar {x}_{i})) +o(\|d\|) \\[1pt]=&\sum _{\bar {x}_{i}=0}(g_{i}(\bar {x})^{T}d_{i}+\lambda |d_{i}|)\\[1pt]&+\, \sum _{0 < |\bar {x}_{i}|\leq \theta \lambda }(g_{i}(\bar {x})+\nabla r_{i}(\bar {x}))d_{i}+ o(\|d\|)\\[1pt]\geq&\sum _{\bar {x}_{i}=0}(\lambda -|g_{i}(\bar {x}))|d_{i}\\[1pt] > &0.\end{align*} Case (2) $d_{\mathcal G(\bar {x})}=0$ . If $\lambda _{\min } > \frac {1}{\theta }$ , by (7) and (8) we have \begin{align*} \varphi (\bar {x}+d)-\varphi (\bar {x})=&\sum _{\bar {x}_{i}=0}(g_{i}(\bar {x})d_{i}+\lambda |d_{i}|)+o(\|d\|^{2}) \\&+\,\sum _{0 < |\bar {x}_{i}|\leq \theta \lambda } \left({g_{i}(\bar {x})+\lambda {{ sgn}}(\bar {x}_{i})-\frac {\bar {x}_{i}}{\theta }}\right)d_{i} \\&+\,\frac {1}{2}d^{T} \nabla ^{2} f(\bar {x}) d+\sum _{|\bar {x}_{i}|\leq \theta \lambda } -\frac {d_{i}^{2}}{2\theta } \\\geq&\sum _{\bar {x}_{i}=0}(\lambda -g_{i}(\bar {x}))|d_{i}| +\frac {\lambda _{\min }}{2}\|d\|^{2} \\&-\,\sum _{|\bar {x}_{i}|\leq \theta \lambda }\frac {d_{i}^{2}}{2\theta }+o(\|d\|^{2}) \\\geq&\frac {\lambda _{\min }}{2}\|d_{\mathcal T_{2}(\bar {x})}\|^{2}+o(\|d\|^{2}) \\&+\,\sum _{|\bar {x}_{i}|\leq \theta \lambda } \left({\frac {\lambda _{\min }}{2}-\frac {1}{2\theta }}\right)d_{i}^{2} > 0\end{align*} View Source\begin{align*} \varphi (\bar {x}+d)-\varphi (\bar {x})=&\sum _{\bar {x}_{i}=0}(g_{i}(\bar {x})d_{i}+\lambda |d_{i}|)+o(\|d\|^{2}) \\&+\,\sum _{0 < |\bar {x}_{i}|\leq \theta \lambda } \left({g_{i}(\bar {x})+\lambda {{ sgn}}(\bar {x}_{i})-\frac {\bar {x}_{i}}{\theta }}\right)d_{i} \\&+\,\frac {1}{2}d^{T} \nabla ^{2} f(\bar {x}) d+\sum _{|\bar {x}_{i}|\leq \theta \lambda } -\frac {d_{i}^{2}}{2\theta } \\\geq&\sum _{\bar {x}_{i}=0}(\lambda -g_{i}(\bar {x}))|d_{i}| +\frac {\lambda _{\min }}{2}\|d\|^{2} \\&-\,\sum _{|\bar {x}_{i}|\leq \theta \lambda }\frac {d_{i}^{2}}{2\theta }+o(\|d\|^{2}) \\\geq&\frac {\lambda _{\min }}{2}\|d_{\mathcal T_{2}(\bar {x})}\|^{2}+o(\|d\|^{2}) \\&+\,\sum _{|\bar {x}_{i}|\leq \theta \lambda } \left({\frac {\lambda _{\min }}{2}-\frac {1}{2\theta }}\right)d_{i}^{2} > 0\end{align*} for any sufficiently small $d \neq 0$ The proof is completed.

SECTION III.

Active Set Estimate

In this section, we propose the active set estimate and give some properties of the active set estimate. We use the following sets $\mathcal Z(x)$ and $\mathcal S(x)$ to approximate ${\mathcal G}(\bar {x})$ and ${\mathcal T}(\bar {x})$ , respectively, \begin{align*} \mathcal Z(x)=&\{i: | x_{i}| \leq \lambda \theta \},\\ \mathcal S(x)=&\{i: |x_{i}| > \lambda \theta \}.\end{align*} View Source\begin{align*} \mathcal Z(x)=&\{i: | x_{i}| \leq \lambda \theta \},\\ \mathcal S(x)=&\{i: |x_{i}| > \lambda \theta \}.\end{align*} Furthermore, we partition $\mathcal Z(x)$ into two parts. That is, \begin{equation*} \mathcal Z_{1}(x)=\{i\in \mathcal Z(x):\; |x_{i}-g_{i}(x)|\leq \lambda \}\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} \mathcal Z_{1}(x)=\{i\in \mathcal Z(x):\; |x_{i}-g_{i}(x)|\leq \lambda \}\end{equation*} and \begin{equation*} \mathcal Z_{2}(x)=\{i\in \mathcal Z(x):\; |x_{i}-g_{i}(x)| > \lambda \}.\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} \mathcal Z_{2}(x)=\{i\in \mathcal Z(x):\; |x_{i}-g_{i}(x)| > \lambda \}.\end{equation*} Below the theorem shows that when the point $x$ is sufficiently close to a stationary point $\bar {x}$ , the set $\mathcal Z_{1}(x)$ is a subset of the set ${\mathcal G}(\bar {x})$ . Furthermore, when ${\mathcal G}_{-}(\bar {x})=\emptyset $ holds, the set $\mathcal Z_{1}(x)$ is actually equal to the set ${\mathcal G}(\bar {x})$ .

Theorem 3:

Assume that $\bar {x}$ is a stationary point of problem (1) and $g(x)$ is continuous on $\mathcal R^{n}$ . Then we have the following statement.

  1. There exists a neighbourhood $\mathcal N(\bar {x})$ of $\bar {x}$ such that \begin{equation*} {\mathcal G}_{+}(\bar {x})\subseteq \mathcal Z_{1}(x)\subseteq \mathcal {\mathcal G}(\bar {x}).\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} {\mathcal G}_{+}(\bar {x})\subseteq \mathcal Z_{1}(x)\subseteq \mathcal {\mathcal G}(\bar {x}).\end{equation*} In particular, if ${\mathcal G}_{-}(\bar {x})=\emptyset $ , then we have \begin{equation*} \mathcal Z_{1}(x)= {\mathcal G}(\bar {x}),\quad \forall x \in \mathcal N(\bar {x}).\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} \mathcal Z_{1}(x)= {\mathcal G}(\bar {x}),\quad \forall x \in \mathcal N(\bar {x}).\end{equation*}

  2. There exists a neighbourhood $\mathcal N(\bar {x})$ of $\bar {x}$ such that \begin{equation*} {\mathcal T}_{2}(\bar {x})\subseteq \mathcal S(x)\subseteq {\mathcal T} _{2}(\bar {x})\cup {\mathcal T} _{3}(\bar {x}),\quad \forall x \in \mathcal N(\bar {x}).\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} {\mathcal T}_{2}(\bar {x})\subseteq \mathcal S(x)\subseteq {\mathcal T} _{2}(\bar {x})\cup {\mathcal T} _{3}(\bar {x}),\quad \forall x \in \mathcal N(\bar {x}).\end{equation*}

  3. There exists a neighbourhood $\mathcal N(\bar {x})$ of $\bar {x}$ such that \begin{equation*} {\mathcal T}_{1}(\bar {x})\subseteq \mathcal Z_{2}(x)\subseteq {\mathcal G} _{-}(\bar {x})\cup {\mathcal T} _{1}(\bar {x})\cup {\mathcal T} _{3}(\bar {x}),\quad \forall x \in \mathcal N(\bar {x}).\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} {\mathcal T}_{1}(\bar {x})\subseteq \mathcal Z_{2}(x)\subseteq {\mathcal G} _{-}(\bar {x})\cup {\mathcal T} _{1}(\bar {x})\cup {\mathcal T} _{3}(\bar {x}),\quad \forall x \in \mathcal N(\bar {x}).\end{equation*}

Proof:

If ${\mathcal G}_{-}(\bar {x})=\emptyset $ holds at $\bar {x}$ , then the second statement in (1) follows from the first statement (1). Thus, it suffices to prove the statement (1). For each $i\in {\mathcal G} _{+}(\bar {x})$ , we have \begin{equation*}\bar {x}_{i}=0 \quad {{ and}}\, |g_{i}(\bar {x})| < \lambda.\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*}\bar {x}_{i}=0 \quad {{ and}}\, |g_{i}(\bar {x})| < \lambda.\end{equation*} By the continuity of $g(x)$ , we have \begin{equation*} |x_{i}|\leq \lambda \theta \quad {{ and}} \, |x_{i}-g_{i}(x)| \leq \lambda\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} |x_{i}|\leq \lambda \theta \quad {{ and}} \, |x_{i}-g_{i}(x)| \leq \lambda\end{equation*} as $x\rightarrow \bar {x}$ . Thus $i\in \mathcal Z_{1}(x)$ as $x\rightarrow \bar {x}$ . For each $i\in \mathcal Z_{1}(x)$ , by the continuity of $g(x)$ , we have \begin{equation*} |\bar {x}_{i}|\leq \lambda \theta \quad {{ and}}\, |\bar {x}_{i}-g_{i}(\bar {x})| \leq \lambda.\tag{9}\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} |\bar {x}_{i}|\leq \lambda \theta \quad {{ and}}\, |\bar {x}_{i}-g_{i}(\bar {x})| \leq \lambda.\tag{9}\end{equation*} We claim that it must hold $\bar {x}_{i}=0$ . In fact, by (4), we get \begin{equation*} |\bar {x}_{i}|=\lambda \theta \quad {{ and}}\, |\bar {x}_{i}-g_{i}(\bar {x})| =\lambda \theta > \lambda\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} |\bar {x}_{i}|=\lambda \theta \quad {{ and}}\, |\bar {x}_{i}-g_{i}(\bar {x})| =\lambda \theta > \lambda\end{equation*} and \begin{equation*} 0\! < \!|\bar {x}_{i}|\! < \!\lambda \theta \quad {{ and}}\, |\bar {x}_{i}-g_{i}(\bar {x})|\!=\!|\left({1-\frac {1}{\theta }}\right)\bar {x}_{i}+{{ sgn}}(\bar {x}_{i})\lambda | > \lambda\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} 0\! < \!|\bar {x}_{i}|\! < \!\lambda \theta \quad {{ and}}\, |\bar {x}_{i}-g_{i}(\bar {x})|\!=\!|\left({1-\frac {1}{\theta }}\right)\bar {x}_{i}+{{ sgn}}(\bar {x}_{i})\lambda | > \lambda\end{equation*} which contradicts (9). Then we get the statement (1).

For each $i\in {\mathcal T} _{2}(\bar {x})$ , by the continuity of $g(x)$ , we have \begin{equation*} |x_{i}| > \lambda \theta \quad {{ and}}\, |x_{i}-g_{i}(x)| \rightarrow |\bar {x}_{i}| > \lambda \theta\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} |x_{i}| > \lambda \theta \quad {{ and}}\, |x_{i}-g_{i}(x)| \rightarrow |\bar {x}_{i}| > \lambda \theta\end{equation*} as $x\rightarrow \bar {x}$ . On the other hand, for each $i\in \mathcal S(x)$ , by (4) we have \begin{equation*} |\bar {x}_{i}| \geq \lambda \theta \quad {{ and}}\, g_{i}(\bar {x})=0.\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} |\bar {x}_{i}| \geq \lambda \theta \quad {{ and}}\, g_{i}(\bar {x})=0.\end{equation*} Thus $i\in {\mathcal T} _{2}(\bar {x})\cup {\mathcal T} _{3}(\bar {x}) $ . For each $i\in {\mathcal T} _{1}(\bar {x})$ , by (4) we have \begin{equation*} \lambda < |\bar {x}_{i}-g_{i}(\bar {x})|=|\left({1-\frac {1}{\theta }}\right)\bar {x}_{i}+{{ sgn}}\,(\bar {x}_{i})\lambda | < \lambda \theta.\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} \lambda < |\bar {x}_{i}-g_{i}(\bar {x})|=|\left({1-\frac {1}{\theta }}\right)\bar {x}_{i}+{{ sgn}}\,(\bar {x}_{i})\lambda | < \lambda \theta.\end{equation*} By the continuity of $g(x)$ , we have $i \in \mathcal Z_{2}(x)$ as $x\rightarrow \bar {x}$ . To get a better descent direction of the new algorithm, we partition $\mathcal Z_{2}(x)$ into $\mathcal Z_{21}(x)$ and $\mathcal Z_{22}(x)$ , respectively, \begin{equation*} \mathcal Z_{21}(x)=\{i\in \mathcal Z_{2}(x): x_{i}-g_{i}(x) > \lambda \}\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} \mathcal Z_{21}(x)=\{i\in \mathcal Z_{2}(x): x_{i}-g_{i}(x) > \lambda \}\end{equation*} and \begin{equation*} \mathcal Z_{22}(x)=\{i\in \mathcal Z_{2}(x): x_{i}-g_{i}(x) < -\lambda \}.\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} \mathcal Z_{22}(x)=\{i\in \mathcal Z_{2}(x): x_{i}-g_{i}(x) < -\lambda \}.\end{equation*} Furthermore, we partition $\mathcal Z_{21}(x)$ and $\mathcal Z_{22}(x)$ into two parts, respectively, \begin{align*} \mathcal Z_{21t}(x)=&\{i\in \mathcal Z_{21}(x):0 < x_{i}\leq \lambda \theta \}, \\ \mathcal Z_{21f}(x)=&\{i\in \mathcal Z_{21}(x):-\lambda \theta \leq x_{i}\leq 0 \}, \\ \mathcal Z_{22t}(x)=&\{i\in \mathcal Z_{22}(x): -\lambda \theta \leq x_{i} < 0\}, \\ \mathcal Z_{22f}(x)=&\{i\in \mathcal Z_{22}(x):0\leq x_{i}\leq \lambda \theta \}.\end{align*} View Source\begin{align*} \mathcal Z_{21t}(x)=&\{i\in \mathcal Z_{21}(x):0 < x_{i}\leq \lambda \theta \}, \\ \mathcal Z_{21f}(x)=&\{i\in \mathcal Z_{21}(x):-\lambda \theta \leq x_{i}\leq 0 \}, \\ \mathcal Z_{22t}(x)=&\{i\in \mathcal Z_{22}(x): -\lambda \theta \leq x_{i} < 0\}, \\ \mathcal Z_{22f}(x)=&\{i\in \mathcal Z_{22}(x):0\leq x_{i}\leq \lambda \theta \}.\end{align*} The following theorem shows that $\mathcal Z_{21f}\cup \mathcal Z_{22f} $ is a subset of the set ${\mathcal G}_{-}(\bar {x})$ when $x$ is sufficiently close to $\bar {x}$ .

Theorem 4:

Assume that $\bar {x}$ is a stationary point of problem (1) and $g(x)$ is continuous on $\mathcal R^{n}$ . Then there exists a neighbourhood $\mathcal N(\bar {x})$ of $\bar {x}$ such that, $\forall x \in \mathcal N(\bar {x})$ , the following statements hold, \begin{align*} \mathcal Z_{21f}(x)\subset&\{i: \bar {x}_{i}=0,\; g_{i}(\bar {x})=\lambda \},\tag{10}\\ \mathcal Z_{22f}(x)\subset&\{i: \bar {x}_{i}=0,\; g_{i}(\bar {x})=-\lambda \},\tag{11}\\ \mathcal Z_{21f}(x)\cup&\mathcal Z_{22f}(x) \subseteq {\mathcal G} _{-}(\bar {x}). \tag{12}\end{align*} View Source\begin{align*} \mathcal Z_{21f}(x)\subset&\{i: \bar {x}_{i}=0,\; g_{i}(\bar {x})=\lambda \},\tag{10}\\ \mathcal Z_{22f}(x)\subset&\{i: \bar {x}_{i}=0,\; g_{i}(\bar {x})=-\lambda \},\tag{11}\\ \mathcal Z_{21f}(x)\cup&\mathcal Z_{22f}(x) \subseteq {\mathcal G} _{-}(\bar {x}). \tag{12}\end{align*}

It is easy to see that (10)–(11) give (12). In the following, we will only prove (10) since by a similar analysis, we can show (11). For each $i\in \mathcal Z_{21f}(\bar {x})$ , by the continuity of $g(x)$ , we have \begin{equation*} -\lambda \theta \leq \bar {x}_{i}\leq 0\quad {{ and}}\, \bar {x}_{i}-g_{i}(\bar {x})\geq \lambda\tag{13}\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} -\lambda \theta \leq \bar {x}_{i}\leq 0\quad {{ and}}\, \bar {x}_{i}-g_{i}(\bar {x})\geq \lambda\tag{13}\end{equation*} Then we must have $\bar {x}_{i}=0$ and $g_{i}(\bar {x})=\lambda $ . In fact, \begin{equation*} \bar {x}_{i}=-\lambda \theta \quad {{ and }}\, \bar {x}_{i}-g_{i}(\bar {x})=-\lambda \theta\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} \bar {x}_{i}=-\lambda \theta \quad {{ and }}\, \bar {x}_{i}-g_{i}(\bar {x})=-\lambda \theta\end{equation*} and \begin{equation*} -\lambda \theta \leq \bar {x}_{i} < 0\quad {{ and }}\, \bar {x}_{i}-g_{i}(\bar {x})\!=\!\left({1-\frac {1}{\theta }}\right)\bar {x}_{i}+{{ sgn}}(\bar {x}_{i})\lambda < 0\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} -\lambda \theta \leq \bar {x}_{i} < 0\quad {{ and }}\, \bar {x}_{i}-g_{i}(\bar {x})\!=\!\left({1-\frac {1}{\theta }}\right)\bar {x}_{i}+{{ sgn}}(\bar {x}_{i})\lambda < 0\end{equation*} which contradicts (13). SECTION IV.

The New Algorithm

In this section, by use of the active set identification technique in Section 3, we shall propose a second-order algorithm for solving problem (1). The following assumptions were made on the objective function.

Assumption 1:

  1. The level set $\Theta:=\{x \in \mathcal R^{n}:\varphi (x)\leq \varphi (x^{0})\}$ is bounded.

  2. In some neighbourhood $\mathcal N$ of $\Theta $ , $f$ is continuously differentiable and its gradient is Lipschitz continuous, i.e., there exists a constant $L > 0$ such that \begin{equation*} \|g(x)-g(y)\|\leq L \|x-y\|, \quad \forall x, y \in \mathcal N.\tag{15}\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} \|g(x)-g(y)\|\leq L \|x-y\|, \quad \forall x, y \in \mathcal N.\tag{15}\end{equation*}

A. Definition and some Properties of the Search Direction

Now, we describe how to compute the search direction in the proposed algorithm. Let $x^{k} \in \Omega $ be the $k$ -th iteration. For simplicity, we let \begin{equation*} \mathcal Z^{k}_{1}=\mathcal Z_{1}(x^{k}),\quad \mathcal I^{k}=\mathcal S(x^{k}), \mathcal I_{1}^{k}=\mathcal Z_{21t}(x^{k})\cup \mathcal Z_{22t}(x^{k})\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} \mathcal Z^{k}_{1}=\mathcal Z_{1}(x^{k}),\quad \mathcal I^{k}=\mathcal S(x^{k}), \mathcal I_{1}^{k}=\mathcal Z_{21t}(x^{k})\cup \mathcal Z_{22t}(x^{k})\end{equation*} and \begin{equation*} \mathcal I_{2}^{k}=\mathcal Z_{21f}(x^{k})\cup \mathcal Z_{22f}(x^{k}).\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} \mathcal I_{2}^{k}=\mathcal Z_{21f}(x^{k})\cup \mathcal Z_{22f}(x^{k}).\end{equation*} Define the search direction $d^{k}=(d^{k}_{\mathcal Z_{1}^{k}},d^{k}_{\mathcal I^{k}_{1}},d^{k}_{\mathcal I^{k}_{2}},d^{k}_{\mathcal I^{k}})$ where \begin{align*} d^{k}_{i}=\begin{cases} \displaystyle -x^{k}_{i}, &{{ if }}\, i \in \mathcal Z_{1}^{k};\\ \displaystyle -(\bar {g}_{i}(x^{k})+{{ sgn}}(x^{k}_{i})\lambda),&{{ if}}\, i \in \mathcal I^{k}_{1},\\ \displaystyle -(\bar {g}_{i}(x^{k})-{{ sgn}} (\bar {g}_{i}(x^{k}))\lambda), & {{ if }}\, i \in \mathcal I^{k}_{2}, \end{cases}\tag{16}\end{align*} View Source\begin{align*} d^{k}_{i}=\begin{cases} \displaystyle -x^{k}_{i}, &{{ if }}\, i \in \mathcal Z_{1}^{k};\\ \displaystyle -(\bar {g}_{i}(x^{k})+{{ sgn}}(x^{k}_{i})\lambda),&{{ if}}\, i \in \mathcal I^{k}_{1},\\ \displaystyle -(\bar {g}_{i}(x^{k})-{{ sgn}} (\bar {g}_{i}(x^{k}))\lambda), & {{ if }}\, i \in \mathcal I^{k}_{2}, \end{cases}\tag{16}\end{align*} where $\bar {g}_{i}(x^{k})=g_{i}(x^{k})-\frac {1}{\theta }x^{k}_{i}$ . We obtain $d^{k}_{\mathcal I^{k}}$ by solving the following linear system \begin{equation*} \nabla ^{2} f^{k}_{\mathcal I^{k},\mathcal I^{k}}(x^{k}) d^{k} _{\mathcal I^{k}}=- g^{k} _{\mathcal I^{k}}.\tag{17}\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} \nabla ^{2} f^{k}_{\mathcal I^{k},\mathcal I^{k}}(x^{k}) d^{k} _{\mathcal I^{k}}=- g^{k} _{\mathcal I^{k}}.\tag{17}\end{equation*} We use the CG algorithm [23] to solve this linear system. An attractive property of the CG algorithm [23] is that it tries to determine a good approximation of the full Newton’s direction even if $\nabla ^{2} f_{\mathcal I^{k},\mathcal I^{k}}(x^{k})$ is not positive definite. It is easy to see that Theorem 2.2 (c) of [23] ensures that there exist positive constants $c_{1}$ and $c_{2}$ such that the direction $d^{k}_{\mathcal I^{k}}$ produced by the CG algorithm satfaisfies the following condition \begin{equation*} (g_{\mathcal I^{k}}^{k})^{T}d^{k}_{\mathcal I^{k}}\leq {-} c_{1} \| g_{\mathcal I^{k}}^{k}\|^{2}\tag{18}\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} (g_{\mathcal I^{k}}^{k})^{T}d^{k}_{\mathcal I^{k}}\leq {-} c_{1} \| g_{\mathcal I^{k}}^{k}\|^{2}\tag{18}\end{equation*} and \begin{equation*} \|d^{k}_{\mathcal I^{k}}\| \leq c_{2}\| g_{\mathcal I^{k}}^{k}\|.\tag{19}\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} \|d^{k}_{\mathcal I^{k}}\| \leq c_{2}\| g_{\mathcal I^{k}}^{k}\|.\tag{19}\end{equation*} Then it follows that \begin{equation*} c_{1}\| g_{\mathcal I^{k}}^{k}\| \leq \|d^{k}_{\mathcal I^{k}}\| \leq c_{2}\| g_{\mathcal I^{k}}^{k}\|.\tag{20}\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} c_{1}\| g_{\mathcal I^{k}}^{k}\| \leq \|d^{k}_{\mathcal I^{k}}\| \leq c_{2}\| g_{\mathcal I^{k}}^{k}\|.\tag{20}\end{equation*} For each $i\in \mathcal I^{k}_{2}$ , we have \begin{equation*} 0\leq x^{k}_{i}\leq \lambda \theta,\quad g_{i}(x^{k}) > x^{k}_{i}+\lambda > \frac {1}{\theta }x^{k}_{i}+\lambda, i\in \mathcal Z_{21f}(x^{k})\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} 0\leq x^{k}_{i}\leq \lambda \theta,\quad g_{i}(x^{k}) > x^{k}_{i}+\lambda > \frac {1}{\theta }x^{k}_{i}+\lambda, i\in \mathcal Z_{21f}(x^{k})\end{equation*} and \begin{equation*} -\lambda \theta \!\leq \!x^{k}_{i}\leq 0,\quad g_{i}(x^{k})\! < \!x^{k}_{i}-\lambda \! < \!\frac {1}{\theta }x^{k}_{i}-\lambda, i\in \mathcal Z_{22f}(x^{k}).\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} -\lambda \theta \!\leq \!x^{k}_{i}\leq 0,\quad g_{i}(x^{k})\! < \!x^{k}_{i}-\lambda \! < \!\frac {1}{\theta }x^{k}_{i}-\lambda, i\in \mathcal Z_{22f}(x^{k}).\end{equation*} Then we have \begin{align*} |d^{k}_{i}|=&|g_{i}(x^{k})-\frac {1}{\theta }x^{k}_{i}-{\mathrm{ sgn}} \left({g_{i}(x^{k})-\frac {1}{\theta }x^{k}_{i}}\right)\lambda | \\=&|g_{i}(x^{k})-\frac {1}{\theta }x^{k}_{i}|-\lambda > 0,\quad i\in \mathcal I^{k}_{2}. \tag{21}\end{align*} View Source\begin{align*} |d^{k}_{i}|=&|g_{i}(x^{k})-\frac {1}{\theta }x^{k}_{i}-{\mathrm{ sgn}} \left({g_{i}(x^{k})-\frac {1}{\theta }x^{k}_{i}}\right)\lambda | \\=&|g_{i}(x^{k})-\frac {1}{\theta }x^{k}_{i}|-\lambda > 0,\quad i\in \mathcal I^{k}_{2}. \tag{21}\end{align*} From Theorem 3, we know that $\mathcal Z_{1}^{k}$ approximates the set ${\mathcal G}(\bar {x})$ when $x^{k} \rightarrow \bar {x}$ . Thus, it is a better choice to fix those variables with indices in $\mathcal Z_{1}^{k}$ to 0. Thus, we set $d^{k}_{i}=-x^{k}_{i}$ , $\forall i\in \mathcal Z_{1}^{k}$ . We will get $x^{k+1}_{i}=0$ for all $i\in \mathcal Z_{1}^{k}$ if the unit steplength is accepted (see Algorithm 1). Below the theorem establishes that $d^{k}=0$ if and only if $x^{k}$ is a stationary point of problem (1).

Algorithm 1 (The New Algorithm)

  • Step 0.

    Initialize an initial guess $x^{0} \in { \mathcal R^{n}}$ and constants $M > 0$ , $\eta > 0$ and $\delta \in (0,1)$ . Set $k:=0$ .

  • Step 1.

    If $x^{k}$ satisfies the stopping condition, then stop. Otherwise, go to Step 2.

  • Step 2.

    Compute $d^{k}$ by (16) and (17).

  • Step 3.

    Determine $\beta ^{k}:=\max \{ \eta ^{j},j=0,1,\cdots \} $ satisfying \begin{equation*} \varphi (x^{k}+\beta ^{k}d^{k})\leq \varphi _{\max }^{k}-\delta (\beta ^{k}\|d^{k}\|)^{2},\tag{22}\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} \varphi (x^{k}+\beta ^{k}d^{k})\leq \varphi _{\max }^{k}-\delta (\beta ^{k}\|d^{k}\|)^{2},\tag{22}\end{equation*} where $\varphi _{\max }^{k}=\max \{\varphi (x^{k-j}): 0\leq j \leq \min (k,M-1) \}$ .

  • Step 4.

    Set $x^{k+1}:=x^{k}+\beta ^{k}d^{k}$ .

  • Step 5.

    Set $k:=k+1$ and go to Step 1.

Theorem 6:

Assume that $d^{k}$ is determined by (16)–​(19). Then $d^{k}=0$ if and only if $x^{k}$ is a stationary point of problem (1).

Proof:

Suppose that $d^{k}=0$ . For each $i\in \mathcal Z_{1}(x^{k})$ and $d^{k}_{i}=-x^{k}_{i}=0$ , we have \begin{equation*} x^{k}_{i}=0\quad {{ and}}\, |g_{i}(x^{k})|\leq \lambda.\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} x^{k}_{i}=0\quad {{ and}}\, |g_{i}(x^{k})|\leq \lambda.\end{equation*} For each $i\in \mathcal S(x^{k})$ , by (20), we get \begin{equation*} |x^{k}_{i}| > \lambda \theta \quad {{ and}}\, g_{i}(x^{k})=0, i\in \mathcal S(x^{k}).\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} |x^{k}_{i}| > \lambda \theta \quad {{ and}}\, g_{i}(x^{k})=0, i\in \mathcal S(x^{k}).\end{equation*} By (21) and the assumption $d^{k}=0$ , we note that $\mathcal Z_{2}^{k}=\emptyset $ . For each $i\in \mathcal Z_{1}^{k}$ , by the definition of $d^{k}_{i}$ and the assumption $d^{k}=0$ , we get \begin{equation*} 0 < |x^{k}_{i}|\leq \lambda \theta \quad {{ and}}\, g_{i}(x^{k})+{{ sgn}}(x^{k}_{i})\lambda -\frac {1}{\theta }x^{k}_{i}=0.\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} 0 < |x^{k}_{i}|\leq \lambda \theta \quad {{ and}}\, g_{i}(x^{k})+{{ sgn}}(x^{k}_{i})\lambda -\frac {1}{\theta }x^{k}_{i}=0.\end{equation*} On the contrary, suppose that $x^{k}$ is a stationary point of problem (1). B. The Algorithm and its Global Convergence

Now, we state the steps of the new algorithm for solving (1) as follows.

The nonmonotone line search condition (22) was introduced by Grippo, Lampariello, and Lucidi (see [23]). It has been successfully incorporated into a variety of optimization algorithms. Substituting (27) into the last inequality, we have \begin{align*}&\hspace {-.5pc} -c_{1} \|d^{k}_{ \mathcal I^{k}}\|^{2} -\left({1-\frac {1}{\theta }}\right)\|d^{k}_{\mathcal Z^{k}_{1}}\|^{2}-\|d^{k}_{\mathcal I^{k}_{1}\cup \mathcal I^{k}_{2}}\|^{2} \\& \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad{{\displaystyle { > -(L+\delta)\frac {\beta ^{k}}{\eta }\|d^{k}\|^{2}. } }}\end{align*} View Source\begin{align*}&\hspace {-.5pc} -c_{1} \|d^{k}_{ \mathcal I^{k}}\|^{2} -\left({1-\frac {1}{\theta }}\right)\|d^{k}_{\mathcal Z^{k}_{1}}\|^{2}-\|d^{k}_{\mathcal I^{k}_{1}\cup \mathcal I^{k}_{2}}\|^{2} \\& \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad{{\displaystyle { > -(L+\delta)\frac {\beta ^{k}}{\eta }\|d^{k}\|^{2}. } }}\end{align*} By the boundedness of $\{d^{k}\}_{k\in \mathcal K}$ , the last inequality and (26), we get \begin{equation*} \lim \limits _{k\in \mathcal K} d^{k}=0.\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} \lim \limits _{k\in \mathcal K} d^{k}=0.\end{equation*} By Lemma 2, we get the conclusion. The proof is completed.

SECTION V.

Numerical Experiments

In this section, computational experiments for testing the performance of the proposed algorithm on the compressed sensing problems (2) are presented. We compare the proposed algorithm with the following three existing solvers: GIST [21], PDASC [24] and MSCR [42]. The MATLAB code (package Unified-PDASC) is available at http://www0.cs.ucl.ac.uk/staff/b.jin/software/updasc.zip. We note that package Unified-PDASC contains the codes GIST [21] and MSCR [42]. “MCP” form of the three codes are implemented with default parameters. All codes are written in MATLAB R2013a and all tests described in this section were performed on a PC with Intel I5-3230 2.6GHZ CPU processor and 16GB RAM memory with a Windows operating system.

In Subsection VI-A, parameter settings and data generated are presented. In Subsection VI-B, the effect of different concave parameters $\theta $ on the proposed algorithm is presented. We compare our method GIST [21], PDASC [24] and MSCR [42] by solving middle-scale problem (2) in Subsection VI-C and by solving large-scale problem (2) in Subsection VI-D. The results in Subsecitons VI-C and VI-D show that our method outperforms GIST [21], PDASC [24] and MSCR [42] both in solution quality and in running time for all most tested problems.

A. Parameters Setting and Data Generation

We now briefly describe the implementation details of Algorithm 1. For convenience, we abbreviate Algorithm 1 as AMCP. We implemented AMCP with the following parameters $M=10$ , $\delta =10^{-2}$ and $\eta =0.6$ . For all the tests, the computation is initialized with zero vector. To obtain a good initial guess, we embed AMCP in a continuation procedure. Specifically, instead of solving problem (1) directly from scratch, we solve a sequence of problems $(x^{\ast}_{\lambda _{k}}:=\arg \min _{x\in \mathcal R^{n}} \big\{\varphi _{\lambda _{k}}(x)=f(x)+\sum _{i=1}^{n}r^{\lambda _{k}}_{i}(x_{i})$ , where $\lambda _{0} > \lambda _{1}\cdots > \lambda _{N}$ , $N$ is a positive integer and \begin{align*} r^{\lambda _{k}}_{i}(x_{i})=\begin{cases} \displaystyle \lambda _{k}\left({|x_{i}|-\frac {x_{i}^{2}}{2\lambda _{k} \theta }}\right), &{{ if}}\, |x_{i}| < \theta \lambda _{k},\\ \displaystyle \frac {\lambda _{k}^{2} \theta }{2},&{{ if}}\, |x_{i}|\geq \theta \lambda _{k}, \end{cases}\end{align*} View Source\begin{align*} r^{\lambda _{k}}_{i}(x_{i})=\begin{cases} \displaystyle \lambda _{k}\left({|x_{i}|-\frac {x_{i}^{2}}{2\lambda _{k} \theta }}\right), &{{ if}}\, |x_{i}| < \theta \lambda _{k},\\ \displaystyle \frac {\lambda _{k}^{2} \theta }{2},&{{ if}}\, |x_{i}|\geq \theta \lambda _{k}, \end{cases}\end{align*} and use the solution (or an approximate solution) $x^{\ast}_{\lambda _{k-1}}$ as the initial estimate of the solution to the next problem. We set $\lambda _{0}=0.5\|A^{T}b\|_{\infty }$ and $\lambda _{N}=\lambda =10^{-10}\lambda _{0}$ . The interval $[\lambda _{N},\lambda _{0}]$ is divided into $N$ equally distributed subintervals in logarithmic scale. The sequence $\{\lambda _{k}\}$ are chosen to be the endpoints of the subintervals. We set $N=30$ in all tested algorithms. In our implementation, at the end of iteration $k$ , the next parameter $\lambda _{k}$ is set to a value smaller than $\lambda _{k-1}$ if the point $x^{k}$ satisfies the condition \begin{equation*} \frac {|\varphi _{\lambda _{k-1}}(x^{k})-\varphi _{\lambda _{k-1}}(x^{k-1})|}{\max (|\varphi _{\lambda _{k-1}}(x^{k})|,|\varphi _{\lambda _{k-1}}(x^{k-1})|,1)\}} \leq \epsilon _{f}\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} \frac {|\varphi _{\lambda _{k-1}}(x^{k})-\varphi _{\lambda _{k-1}}(x^{k-1})|}{\max (|\varphi _{\lambda _{k-1}}(x^{k})|,|\varphi _{\lambda _{k-1}}(x^{k-1})|,1)\}} \leq \epsilon _{f}\end{equation*} where $\epsilon _{f}=0.01$ . We implemented the CG algorithm in [23] to solve (17) with parameters $c=\sigma =10^{-8}$ . In many applications, it is not necessary and wasteful to obtain an exact solution at each iteration of (17) when $|\mathcal I^{k}|$ is large. Thus we use only an approximate solution of system (17) and also terminate the CG algorithm if one of the following is satisfied:

  1. $r^{j}\leq \max \{10^{-1}r^{0},10^{-12}\}$ ;

  2. $\|d^{j}\| \geq:=\max \{0.05, \min \{10^{3}, 10\|x^{k}-x^{k-1}\|\}\}$ ;

  3. the maximum number of CG iterations exceeds 10.

In the above, $d^{j}$ denotes the direction of the $j$ th CG iteration and $r^{j}$ denotes the residual of the $j$ th CG iteration. It is easy to see that Theorem 2.2 (c) of [23] ensures that there exist positive constants $c_{1}$ and $c_{2}$ such that the direction $d^{k}_{\mathcal I^{k}}$ produced by the CG algorithm satfaisfies conditions (18)–​(20).

In the following subsections, we demonstrate the viability of our approach and focus on the problems from compressed sensing. Namely, we consider the problem (2), where the goal is to reconstruct a lenghth-$n$ sparse signal from $m$ observations, where $m < n$ . Given the dimension of the signal $n$ and the number of observations $m$ , we generated a random matrix $A$ as follows. The type of matrix $A$ was chosen from the following types:

  1. DCT matrix.

  2. orthogonalized Gaussian matrix whose rows are orthogonalized using a QR.

  3. Sparse normally distributed random matrix.

Types (1) and (2) of matrix $A$ were generated by the code [A, b, xs, xsn, picks] = getData(m, n, k, Ameth, xmeth, varargin) [40]. For each test problem, we stop all tested methods if the condition \begin{equation*} \|Ax^{\ast}_{\lambda _{k}}-b\|\leq \epsilon\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} \|Ax^{\ast}_{\lambda _{k}}-b\|\leq \epsilon\end{equation*} where $\epsilon =\|e\| $ and $e$ is the noise of the data $b$ .

B. Effect of the Concave Parameter $\theta$

In the experiment, we examines the sensitivity of the algorithm with respect to the concavity parameter $\theta $ . The type of measure matrix $A$ is DCT matrix. The observation $b$ is generated by $b = Ax^{\ast} + e$ , where $e$ is drawn according to the Gaussian distribution with zero mean and variance 10-2. To generate the true signal $x^{\ast}$ , we first generated the support $\mathcal A^{\ast}=\{i|\;\;x^{\ast}_{i}\neq 0\}$ by randomly selecting $T$ indices between 1 and $n$ and then assigned the sign of a normally distributed random variable to $x^{\ast}_{i}$ for each $i$ in $\mathcal A^{\ast}$ . The performance is evaluated in terms of CPU time in seconds (time) and the error (error = $\|x^{k}-x^{\ast}\|_{\infty }$ ), which are computed as the average of 10 independent realizations of the problem. Table 1 lists the average CPU time and the average error for each problem. From Table 1, we see that the CPU time is fairly robust with respect to the concavity of parameter $\theta $ . Further, the average error varies little with the parameter $\theta $ , indicating the robustness of AMCP. In all the following tests, we set the parameter $\theta =2.7$ .

C. Reconstruction From Noise Observation for Middle-Scale Problems

In the experiment, the type of the measure matrix $A$ is orthogonalized Gaussian matrix whose rows are orthogonalized using a QR. The true signal $x^{\ast}$ is a random sparse vector with $T$ -sparse signal with a support $\mathcal A^{\ast}$ . The dynamical range $R$ of the true signal $x^{\ast}$ is defined by $R=\frac {M}{m}$ with $M=\max \{|x^{\ast}_{i}|:\; i\in \mathcal A^{\ast}\}$ and $m=\min \{|x^{\ast}_{i}|:\; i\in \mathcal A^{\ast}\}$ . The $T$ nonzero spike positions are chosen randomly and the nonzeros values are chosen randomly from $[m,M]$ . The observation data $b$ is generated by \begin{equation*} b=Ax^{\ast}+e\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} b=Ax^{\ast}+e\end{equation*} where $e$ is drawn according to the Gaussian distribution with zero mean and variance 10-2. In the experiment, we consider a range of degrees of sparseness: the number $T$ of nonzero spikes in $x^{\ast}$ ranges from 1 to 100 in the support. We set $n=10^{4}$ and $m=round(0.2*n)$ . In the following figures, we use “CPU time” to denote the CPU time in seconds and “error” to denote the error (error $=\|x^{\ast}-x^{k}\|_{\infty }$ )). “CPU time” and “error” are computed on the average of 10 independent realizations of the problem. To have more insights into the numerical results, we utilize the performance profiles by Dolan and Moré [14] to evaluate “CPU time” and “error” in Figures 1–​4. From Figures 1–​4, we observe that AMCP is faster than UPDASC, and UPDASC is faster than GIST and MSCR. Moreover, for most problems, we also observe that AMCP obtains the similar error as the one of UPDASC for most problems and the error obtained by AMCP and UPDASC is better than the error obtained by GIST and MSCR.

D. Reconstruction From Noise Observation for Large-Scale Problems

In the experiment, we use the MATLAB command sprandn (m, n, density) to generate the random matrices $A$ . We also adjusted each column of $A$ such that the norm of each column of $A$ is one. The true signal $x^{\ast}$ and the observation $b$ were generated by the same way as the second experiment. We set the parameter “density” = 0.01 for $n=2^{16}, 2^{17},2^{18}$ and “density” = 0.001 for 219. Table 2 lists the CPU time (time) and the error (error = $\|x^{k}-x^{\ast}\|_{\infty }$ ). From Table 2, we can see that AMCP, PDASC and GIST obtain the similar error when $n\leq 2^{17}$ and both AMCP and PDASC obtain the similar error for all tested problems. In summary, we can observe clearly that AMCP obtains the best CPU time and the best error among all tested algorithms for most problems.

SECTION VI.

Conclusion

In this article, an active set second-order algorithm for MCP regularized optimization is proposed. The active sets are estimated by an identification technique that can accurately identify the zero components in a neighbourhood of a stationary point. The search direction consists of two parts: some of the components are simply defined; the other components are determined by a second-order algorithm. A nonmonotone line search strategy that guarantees global convergence is used. The numerical comparisons with several state-of-art methods demonstrate the efficiency of the proposed method.
